Overview.Summary: Communist Party leader Petro Symonenko withdrew his candidacy from the 2014 Ukrainian presidential election (1). He was originally nominated by the party in March of that year (2). Business tycoon Petro Poroshenko ultimately won the election with 54% of the vote (3,5,10). A former boxer and opposition leader, Vitali Klitschko, also dropped out of the race to support Poroshenko (4). The election was originally scheduled for March 2015 but was moved to May 2014 due to protests (7). During a session of parliament, members of the right-wing Svoboda Party physically attacked Symonenko while he was speaking (8). The election marked a peaceful transfer of power in Ukraine (9).

Timeline.Text: Communist leader Petro Symonenko withdraws his candidacy from the 2014 Ukrainian presidential election.
The 47th extraordinary congress of the Communist Party of Ukraine nominates Petro Symonenko as their candidate for the presidential election.
The presidential election takes place in Ukraine, with pro-European billionaire Petro Poroshenko winning.
Boxer-turned-opposition leader Vitali Klitschko drops out of the presidential election and announces his support for Petro Poroshenko.
Petro Poroshenko is declared the winner of the Ukrainian presidential election.
Communist leader Petro Symonenko is physically attacked by members of the right-wing Svoboda Party while speaking at the Ukrainian parliament.

Overview.Summary: In the 2014 Ukrainian presidential election, Dmytro Yarosh, leader of the Right Sector organization, was a controversial candidate (1,2,3,4,6,9,10). He was wanted in Russia on terrorism charges (3) and was known for his far-right views (7). The election also saw the defeat of other nationalist candidates (1,5). Around 2 million Ukrainians were prevented from voting in the East due to separatist forces (1,5). The election was originally scheduled for March 2015 but was moved to May 2014 due to countrywide protests (8). Other notable candidates included Petro Poroshenko, Yulia Tymoshenko, and Serhiy Tyhypko (9,10).

Timeline.Text: Ukrainians vote in the presidential election, with controversial figure Dmytro Yarosh among the candidates.
Dmytro Yarosh is erroneously reported as leading the presidential election on Russian state TV.
The separatist forces in Eastern Ukraine prevent around 2 million Ukrainians from voting in the presidential election.
The date of the presidential election is moved up from March 2015 to May 2014 due to countrywide protests.

Overview.Summary: The 2014 Ukrainian presidential election (4) took place on May 25 (4). Billionaire Petro Poroshenko declared victory (6) with 56% of the vote (6). His victory was attributed to the lack of serious political competition (2). Other candidates included nationalist Oleh Tiahnybok (1,8) and Dmytro Yarosh (2,3,8), who received 1.3% and 0.9% of the vote respectively (3). The election saw the defeat of nationalist candidates (3,8) and was marked by tensions and separatist forces in the country's east (3,9).

Timeline.Text: Oleh Tiahnybok, leader of the nationalist party Swoboda, is named as a candidate for the 2014 Ukrainian presidential election.
Ukrainian President Viktor Yanukovych announces an early presidential election and a return to an earlier constitution in concessions aimed at finding an end to the ongoing turmoil in the country.
The 47th extraordinary congress of the Communist Party of Ukraine nominates Petro Symonenko as their candidate for the presidential election.
Billionaire Petro Poroshenko declares victory in the presidential election, with preliminary exit polls showing he received 56% of the vote.
The election results show that nationalist candidates Oleh Tyahnybok and Dmytro Yarosh received 1.3% and 0.9% of the vote, respectively.
Oleh Lyashko (Parti radical) comes in third place with 8% of the vote, and independent candidate Serhiy Tihipko receives less than 5% of the vote.
Jewish Agency opens an aliya hotline and the Kiev Jews establish a self-defense group as tensions continue in the divided country.
An infographic is released showing the results of the presidential election, which was originally scheduled for March 29, 2015 but was moved up following countrywide protests.

Overview.Summary: In the 2014 Ukrainian presidential election, billionaire Petro Poroshenko emerged as the leader with 54% of the vote counted (1, 9). According to an opinion poll, Poroshenko had a chance of winning the election in the first round (2). Exit polls indicated that he won with 56% of the vote (5). He was sworn in on June 7 as the fifth president of Ukraine (6, 7). Poroshenko faced challenges such as uniting a divided country and dealing with Russia (7). He was also known as the "Chocolate King" due to his confectionery business (10).

Timeline.Text: Exit polls indicate that Petro Poroshenko is the clear frontrunner in the Ukrainian presidential election.
The media begins to refer to Petro Poroshenko as the 'Chocolate King'.
Petro Poroshenko leads with 54% of the vote counted in the Ukrainian presidential election.
Petro Poroshenko is sworn in as the fifth president of Ukraine.

Overview.Summary: In 2014, Yulia Tymoshenko announced her candidacy for the Ukrainian presidential election, which was scheduled for May 25 (1,2,3,7,10). The election was originally planned for March 2015 but was moved due to protests and the ousting of then-president Viktor Yanukovich (8). Tymoshenko, a former prime minister, was seen as a top candidate in the election (6). However, in the end, billionaire Petro Poroshenko won the election with 54% of the vote (9).

Timeline.Text: Former Ukrainian Prime Minister Yulia Tymoshenko announces she will run for president in the upcoming elections on May 25.
The 2014 Ukrainian presidential election takes place, with Yulia Tymoshenko as one of the candidates.

Overview.Summary: The 2014 Ukrainian presidential election took place on May 25 (1,2,3,5,6,9,10). Billionaire Petro Poroshenko won the election with 56% of the vote (5,10). Serhiy Tihipko, a former ally of Yanukovych, was also a candidate and received less than 5% of the vote (2,4,7,8). Poroshenko's victory was declared in the first round (10). The election was originally scheduled for March 29, 2015 but was moved due to countrywide protests (6).

Timeline.Text: A poll shows that Serhiy Tihipko is expected to receive 4% of the votes in the upcoming Ukrainian presidential election.

Overview.Summary: The 2014 Ukrainian presidential election saw the defeat of nationalist candidates, including Oleh Tyahnybok (1,3,5,8,9). Tyahnybok's party, Svoboda, only received 1.3% of the vote (1,3,5). In a recent poll conducted in May, Tyahnybok's support was below 1% (8). He was also identified as a far-right leader (6). However, some believe that Tyahnybok represents stability and will not sell out Ukraine (9).

Timeline.Text: A Socis opinion poll predicts Petro Poroshenko will win the first round of the presidential election with 48.4% of the vote. Oleh Tyahnybok, leader of the nationalist Svoboda party, is predicted to receive 2.1% of the vote.

A poll conducted on 6-8 May predicts that Petro Poroshenko will win the presidential election with a significant lead. Oleh Tyahnybok of the Svoboda party is predicted to receive only a small percentage of the vote.
Oleh Tyahnybok of the nationalist Svoboda party is seen as a stable candidate for the upcoming presidential election.
The presidential election is seen as a potential ushering in of the direct rule of oligarchs in Ukraine. Oleh Tyahnybok of the Svoboda party is predicted to receive a small percentage of the vote.

Overview.Summary: Vadim Rabinovich, a Ukrainian Jewish oligarch, ran for president in the 2014 Ukrainian presidential election (2,6,7,9). He was one of the candidates in the election, with Petro Poroshenko ultimately winning (1,3,8,10). Rabinovich also founded Jewish News One, which later became Ukraine News 1 (5). The election was originally scheduled for March 29, 2015 but was moved to May 25, 2014 due to countrywide protests (4).

Timeline.Text: Ukrainian Jewish businessman Vadim Rabinovich announces his presidential bid.
Rabinovich claims to be the 'Obama of Ukraine' and believes he still has a chance to win the election.
Ukraine holds its presidential election, with billionaire Petro Poroshenko declared the winner.

Overview.Summary: Mykhailo Dobkin, a former governor and mayor from Kharkiv, was a strong supporter of ex-president Yanukovych and even called for the capital to be relocated to Kharkiv (3,9). Despite his ties to Yanukovych, Dobkin was nominated by the Party of Regions as their presidential candidate (8,10). He has also called for a federal structure in Ukraine and has been described as a radical pro-Russian (9). However, in the end, billionaire Petro Poroshenko declared victory in the presidential election (2,5).

Timeline.Text: Former Kharkiv governor Mykhailo Dobkin is announced as a candidate for the Ukrainian presidential election by the Party of Regions.
Mykhailo Dobkin, a staunch supporter of former president Viktor Yanukovych, is nominated as a presidential candidate for the Party of Regions.

Mykhailo Dobkin, presidential candidate for the Party of Regions, states that the Verkhovna Rada memorandum will be the first step towards stabilization and restoring confidence in Ukrainian politicians.
Mykhailo Dobkin, a former governor of Kharkiv oblast and mayor of Kharkiv city, is noted as a long-time supporter of former president Viktor Yanukovych.
Ukrainian billionaire Petro Poroshenko declares victory in the presidential election, with preliminary exit polls showing he received 56% of the vote.
Billionaire Petro Poroshenko leads in the presidential election with 54% of the vote counted.
The presidential election is scheduled for May 25, following countrywide protests and the ousting of former president Viktor Yanukovych.
Mykhailo Dobkin is introduced as the Party of Regions' presidential candidate by five stalwart members of the former ruling party.
Mykhailo Dobkin, a pro-Russian businessman and former governor of Kharkiv, is announced as the Party of Regions' presidential candidate.

Overview.Summary: The 2014 Ukrainian presidential election (9) was highly charged and seen as a beginning to repairing the country (5). Billionaire Petro Poroshenko (1,2,4,6,8) was the clear favorite and ultimately claimed victory (8). The election was originally scheduled for March 2015 (3) but was moved to May 25, 2014 (2,4,7,9,10). Israeli officials welcomed the results of the election (6), while Russian President Vladimir Putin stated that Russia would recognize the outcome (10). The election was deemed to have taken place regardless of the number of votes (9).

Timeline.Text: Russian President Vladimir Putin announces that Russia will recognize the outcome of the upcoming Ukrainian presidential election.
The Ukrainian presidential election is seen as a beginning to repairing the country after months of protests and turmoil.
Ukrainians vote in a highly-charged presidential election, with chocolate tycoon Petro Poroshenko as the clear favorite.
Billionaire Petro Poroshenko leads in early election results for the Ukrainian presidential election.
An infographic is published about the Ukrainian presidential election, which was originally scheduled for March 29, 2015 but was moved to May 25, 2014.
Israeli officials congratulate Ukraine on its presidential election and express hope for peace and territorial integrity.
Ukraine's presidential election is deemed legitimate by Andriy Magera.
Petro Poroshenko claims victory in the Ukrainian presidential election and vows to bring peace to the country.

Overview.Summary: In the 2014 Ukrainian presidential election, billionaire Petro Poroshenko (3,4,5) won with over 55% of the vote (5). The election was originally scheduled for March 29, 2015, but was moved to May 25, 2014 (2). Over 2 million Ukrainians were prevented from voting due to separatist forces (1). The election was deemed legitimate regardless of the voter turnout (6). Russian state TV initially reported that Dmytro Yarosh led the polls, but this was later found to be erroneous (7). Israel congratulated Ukraine on the election, but remained silent on the issue of territorial integrity (9). Russian President Vladimir Putin stated that Russia would recognize the outcome of the election (10).

Timeline.Text: Billionaire candy-maker Petro Poroshenko wins the Ukrainian presidential election, according to an exit poll.
Russian state TV erroneously reports that Dmytro Yarosh, leader of the Ukrainian far-right group Right Sector, leads the field in the presidential election.
Ukraine's presidential election is deemed legitimate, regardless of the number of voters, according to the country's election law.
Israeli officials welcome the results of the Ukrainian presidential election, but remain silent on the issue of territorial integrity.
Russian President Vladimir Putin declares that Russia will recognize the outcome of the Ukrainian presidential election.
An infographic is released that shows the results of the Ukrainian presidential election.
Preliminary results show that the Ukrainian presidential election is headed for a runoff.

Overview.Summary: The 2014 Ukrainian presidential election (10) was marked by violence and conflict with Euromaidan supporters (1). The winner of the election was Petro Poroshenko, a billionaire who supported the Maidan against Viktor Yanukovych (2,6). The elections were seen as illegitimate by some, with accusations of corruption and oligarchy (3,4,7). The average Euromaidan protestor was 36 years old and had a higher education (8). The election was originally scheduled for March 29, 2015, but was moved to May 25, 2014 (9). There were also attempts to disrupt the election through cyber-attacks (10).

Timeline.Text: A Ukrainian presidential candidate gets into a fight with Euromaidan supporters while visiting pro-Russian separatists at a hospital.
Petro Poroshenko, a supporter of the Euromaidan movement, wins the presidential election in the first round.
The left-wing organization Union of Borotba criticizes the elections as being unfair and illegitimate.
An infographic shows the results of the presidential election, including the average demographics of Euromaidan protesters.
Ukraine narrowly avoids cyber-attacks aimed at disrupting the presidential election.
The election date is moved from March 29, 2015 to May 25, 2014 due to protests.

Overview.Summary: The 2014 Ukrainian presidential election was won by billionaire Petro Poroshenko (1,2,3,5,6,7,10) on May 25, 2014 (1,3,4,5,6,7,10). His closest challenger was former Prime Minister Yulia Tymoshenko (3). The election was initially scheduled for March 29, 2015 but was moved to May 25, 2014 (4). Russian Foreign Minister Sergey Lavrov questioned the validity of the election due to the ongoing conflict in Ukraine (9).

Timeline.Text: Petro Poroshenko, the billionaire owner of Ukrainian chocolate manufacture Roshen and frontrunner in Ukraine's presidential election, speaks during an interview with Reuters in Kiev.
Russian Foreign Minister Sergey Lavrov questions the timing of Ukraine's presidential election while troops are deployed against the population.
Ukraine's current constitution prescribes a democratically legitimatized President, leading to discussions about the upcoming presidential election.
Billionaire Petro Poroshenko declared victory in Ukraine's presidential election, following preliminary exit polls that suggested he got 56% of the vote.
An exit poll shows that billionaire candy-maker Petro Poroshenko won Ukraine's presidential election outright in the first round.
Ukrainian confectionery tycoon Petro Poroshenko has a chance of winning the May 25 presidential election in the first round.
Ukrainian confectionery tycoon Petro Poroshenko claims outright victory in the country's presidential election.
Petro Poroshenko, a billionaire chocolate manufacturer, takes on a fraught mission to quell pro-Russian rebels and restore stability in Ukraine after claiming victory in the presidential election.
Billionaire Petro Poroshenko leads with 54% of the vote counted in Ukraine's presidential election.
An election is scheduled on May 25 to elect a new Ukrainian president for a five-year term.

Overview.Summary: Billionaire Petro Poroshenko won the 2014 Ukrainian presidential election with 54% of the vote (1,6). The election was deemed legitimate according to Ukrainian law (7). The election was originally scheduled for March 29, 2015 but was moved to May 25, 2014 (4). Despite attempts by hackers to disrupt the election, it was narrowly avoided (5). Russian President Vladimir Putin stated that Russia would recognize the outcome of the election (9).

Timeline.Text: Voting begins in Ukraine's presidential election, with billionaire Petro Poroshenko as the clear favorite.
Petro Poroshenko leads in early election results, with 54% of the vote counted.
Russian President Vladimir Putin announces that Russia will recognize the outcome of the Ukrainian presidential election.
Billionaire candy-maker Petro Poroshenko wins Ukraine's presidential election outright in the first round.
Pro-Russian unrest in Ukraine includes a demand for a referendum on a federal status and the abolishment of the presidential election.
An election is held to choose a new Ukrainian president for a five-year term.
A three-pronged wave of cyber-attacks aimed at disrupting the Ukrainian presidential vote is narrowly defeated.
Andriy Magera states that the Ukrainian presidential election will be deemed to have taken place regardless of the number of votes.

Overview.Summary: The 2014 Ukrainian presidential election occurred on May 25, and Petro Poroshenko declared victory with 54% of the vote (1,4). He is a billionaire and the owner of a chocolate company, and has had conflicts with Russia (6). Dobkin, a former governor with ties to ousted President Yanukovych, also ran for president (2,3,7,9,10). The election was originally scheduled for March 29, 2015, but was moved up due to protests (8).

Timeline.Text: Mykhailo Dobkin is introduced as the Party of Regions' candidate for the Ukrainian presidential election.
Petro Poroshenko, a billionaire chocolate baron, emerges as a frontrunner in the presidential election.
Mykhailo Dobkin is nominated as a presidential candidate by Yanukovych's Party of Regions.
Masked men storm Kharkiv City Hall, a location closely associated with Mykhailo Dobkin.
The Ukrainian presidential election takes place, with Petro Poroshenko declared the winner.
An infographic provides information on the 2014 Ukrainian presidential election.

Overview.Summary: Businessman and billionaire Petro Poroshenko declared victory in the 2014 Ukrainian presidential election (2, 10). He received 54% of the vote with 56% of the vote counted (1). Despite violence and threats in the east, the election was characterized by high turnout and was largely in line with international commitments (8). The election, which was originally scheduled for March 29, was moved to May 25 following countrywide protests (3). The election was deemed legitimate by Andriy Magera, a representative of the Ukrainian election law (4). The voter turnout was over 60% (9).

Timeline.Text: Billionaire Petro Poroshenko declares victory in the Ukrainian presidential election.
The Central Election Commission reports a voter turnout of over 60% in the early presidential election, despite violence and threats in the east.
Billionaire Petro Poroshenko leads in early election results.
An infographic is released with information about the Ukrainian presidential election.
The July 9 presidential election in Indonesia is compared to the Ukrainian presidential election.
Andriy Magera states that the Ukrainian presidential election will be legitimate.
An opinion poll indicates that Petro Poroshenko has a chance of winning the presidential election in the first round.
The Ukrainian presidential election is declared a defeat for nationalist candidates.

Overview.Summary: The 2014 Ukrainian presidential election saw billionaire Petro Poroshenko as the front runner and eventual winner with 54% of the vote (1,3). The election also saw defeat for nationalist candidates Oleh Tyahnybok and Dmytro Yarosh (2). Poroshenko's victory was declared on May 25, 2014 (4,8), after being postponed from March 29, 2014 due to countrywide protests (5). Other candidates included Petro Symonenko, Serhiy Tihipko, and Oleh Liashko (6,7,10). Liashko was shown humiliating a captured separatist leader in a video that circulated during the election (9).

Timeline.Text: Presidential elections take place in Ukraine, with oligarch Petro Poroshenko winning 54% of the votes.
Radical politician Oleh Liashko receives 8% of the votes in the presidential election.
The separatist forces in Eastern Ukraine prevent approximately 2 million Ukrainians from voting in the presidential election.
Oleh Liashko interrogates captured separatist leader Igor Kakidzyanov, who is shown in a widely circulated video.

Overview.Summary: The 2014 Ukrainian presidential election took place on May 25, 2014 (2,3,4,20). The election was held after the EuroMaidan Revolution and the ousting of former president Viktor Yanukovych (17). Yulia Tymoshenko, a former prime minister, announced her candidacy on March 27, 2014 (2,11,13,15). Billionaire Petro Poroshenko emerged as the winner with 54% of the vote (3,12,17,20). The presidential race also featured other candidates such as Oleh Tihipko (4,6,14), Serhiy Tihipko (4,6,14), and Dmytro Yarosh (5,12), who received smaller percentages of the vote. The separatist forces in Eastern Ukraine prevented approximately 2 million people from voting (5).

Timeline.Text: Yulia Tymoshenko announces her candidacy for the Ukrainian presidential election on May 25.
Yulia Tymoshenko is profiled as one of Ukraine's top presidential candidates.
Petro Poroshenko wins the Ukrainian presidential election in the first round with over 55% of the vote.
Petro Poroshenko attributes his victory to the lack of serious political competition.
The Central Elections Commission confirms Petro Poroshenko's victory in the Ukrainian presidential election.
Yulia Tymoshenko announces she will run for the presidency in the upcoming Ukrainian presidential election.
Former Ukrainian presidential candidate Oleh Tiahnybok denounces the separatist forces in Eastern Ukraine for preventing people from voting in the presidential election.
Mykhailo Dobkin, former governor of Kharkiv Oblast, announces he will run for president under the Party of Regions banner.
Yulia Tymoshenko announces her candidacy for the Ukrainian presidential election in May 2014.
A Ukrainian presidential candidate gets into a fight with local Euromaidan supporters while trying to visit pro-Russian separatists at a hospital in southern Ukraine.
